Came on a Sunday night, they were busy due to understaffing (2 ppl running the floor. Owner and a worker). Both the worker and owner told us to help ourself with drinks, while we wait for a table. They had soda and milk teas. Service was slow but can't really complain, after all they are under staffed, I just helped myself with the drinks and whatever I need I just grabbed, they didn't really care. Owner is really really nice, didn't charge us for the drinks, so I guess is AYCE and DRINKS for $22.99.
author: Jimmy C.

description: This is my first time eating hot pot, so this isn't a review of an experienced hot pot goer. However, the experience was fantastic!
author: Kirpa S.

description:
One of the better restaurants on san bruno ave.
+wide selection
+good quality meats
+all you can drink milk tea
+great price
+decent sauce bar
+tasty broth
+nice waitresses
+get the fish cod
+fried dough with condensed milk was good
+/- meat portions are small but that could be a good thing because there is less chance of wasting food(you have to pay if you waste food)

-service is not as attentive as more people come
-had to ask multiple times to get the milk tea refill
-language barrier(chinese speakers)

Overall good experience.
Good food and Good service. The price is cheap. the people is nice.  The environment is clean.
author: Sam L.

description: If you haven't, you must check out this spot! One of the cleanest Chinese restaurants I have been to. You have a variety of choices of good quality Hong Kong BBQ and hot pot (17 soup based) you can choose from. I highly recommend Chafing Pot and Kimchi Soup! Will definitely come back!
author: Vann L.

description: We came a few times already since its grand opening.  A very clean and bright restaurant, with friendly staff.  Joanna was our sever, she is cheerful and sweet, always explains the menu patiently and gives good suggestion, and she can speak fair English.  The young boss lady Miss Li is also very friendly with a big smile.  Other than the $23 all you can eat hot pot, which I already saw good comments, they also have regular dishes.  We had steamed pork, fish fillet with green beans, and "Choi sum" - very fresh vegetables and ingredients.  They even have congee!  I haven't been to a Chinese restaurant that offers such a great variety on the menu. Perfect for casual dinners.
author: Portia C.

description: Hubby found article on Hoodline and we decided to give it a try. What a great addition to downtown Portola (San Bruno Av.). All ingredients were very good - great selections of meat, seafood and veggies, all fresh, we got 2 types of broths: Spicy Mayo and Pork Bone. Both were very good. Service was excellent. Will definitely go back and bring friends with us.
author: Joanna L.

description: Walking past, you might think this is another typical Chinese BBQ spot.  Ducks and pork hang in the window, however, Chef Li's is on another level.  It's simply the best Chinese BBQ I've had in SF.  The duck was melt-in-your mouth tender, and the pork was perfectly seasoned.  This is what Chinese BBQ is supposed to be.
author: Aneil M.

description: I dont really like this place, but  their food is pretty good but if you ask for a refill in a milk tea you have to wait like an hour.
author: Damon H.

description: One of the best Chinese food place in SF! Went there 3 times in a row Lunch and Dinner! The size of the the plate is huge and server is really nice offering you WiFi! Will definitely go back to eat if visit to San Francisco again!
author: Jessica L.

description: First time coming to this chef li's. It is fairly new as of June 2017. All you can eat hot pot is $23 per person with two people it will come out to about $58 with tax and tip. We told them it was our first time there and the waitresses were helpful showing us the menu and how to order. Step 1 choose a milk tea their free milk tea options are jasmine green, thai tea, black tea, and two others I can't remember. They do not include the tapioca balls just the milk tea. Step 2 choose the type of broth you would like my brother got the spicy broth the first one and I tried the thai thom ka spicy broth which was way spicier than the spicy broth. There are about 17 options of broth. Step 3 after choosing the broth you can take some time to look over the meats, veggies, tofu, appetizers, and dim sum options. You will mark down on the menu with an expo marker what you would like and how many servings of each you would like. If you want to try a lot of items mark down a 1 so you won't get super full on a couple of items. If you know that everyone at your party really wants a whole plateful of one of the items mark the number of people at your table. Once you are done marking your waitress will pick up the menu and hand it over to the kitchen. In the meantime you will have milk tea to sip on and your hot pot broth will be brought over to boil. There are 5 heat levels that you can turn with the knob. Once your hot pot is boiling we found setting 2 or 3 to be the most comfortable. Step 4 pick out herbs, toppings, and sauces for your hot pot. I tried the satay sauce super yummy and the peanut sauce which was just okay. I also picked up cilantro, green onions, and garlic. My brother added more chili sauce to his hotpot but mine was plenty spicy. Step 5 Then your first order comes out and you can go crazy! If you finish your first order and want more food you can order more rounds as hotpot is all you can eat. You can also order the appetizers and dim sum we tried the tripe and dumplings. For the meats we tried lamb, waygu beef, fish fillet, shrimp, rib eye, pork belly, and squid. For the veggies we tried the napa cabbage, mushrooms, bok choy, squash, winter melon, broccoli, and probably more. They give you a lot of each so we enjoyed ordering one serving and splitting to have more variety. We went through the first round and decided to order a few more things. It is important to pace yourself. The ladies brought by napkins and took away plates efficiently overall a great experience.
author: Lauren R.
